major_uncertainties: Could be fresh chopped herbs (very low calories) versus a dense sauce/chutney (which may contain oil, nuts, or sugar and be much higher calorie).
Could be a green paste (pesto/guacamole) rather than loose herbs — paste would be higher calorie per volume.
Small bowl volume versus loose-leaf packing: whether the 0.170 L corresponds to lightly packed herbs or a dense paste greatly changes estimated weight and calories.
analysis_results.most_important_question: Is this a bowl of fresh chopped herbs (e.g., cilantro/parsley) or is it a prepared sauce/chutney/dressing (e.g., pesto, chutney, guacamole)?

major_uncertainties: Could instead be a vegetarian alternative with similar appearance (paneer or tofu) — paneer is much higher in calories than tofu or lean chicken.
Unknown cooking method: fried/battered vs grilled/roasted — frying would add substantial calories from oil.
Sauce composition is unknown (sugar-heavy glaze vs light savory sauce) which can change calories significantly.
Estimated volume may include surrounding sauce, and it’s unclear what fraction is solid protein versus sauce.
analysis_results.most_important_question: Is this item chicken (meat) or a vegetarian alternative such as paneer or tofu?

major_uncertainties: This could be riced/cauliflower 'rice' (very low calories) rather than real cooked white rice (large calorie difference).
It might be rice prepared with added coconut milk or other high-calorie mix-ins (higher calories) versus plain steamed rice.
analysis_results.most_important_question: Is the highlighted item regular cooked/steamed white rice or cauliflower (riced) cauliflower?

major_uncertainties: Could be plain raw or vinegar-based shredded red/purple cabbage (very low calories, ~20–30 kcal/100g).
Could be a mayonnaise/cream-based coleslaw (much higher calories, ~200–300 kcal/100g) which greatly raises calorie estimate.
Could be pickled/sweetened red cabbage or cooked/braised with oil and sugar (moderately higher calories than raw).
analysis_results.most_important_question: Is this shredded purple/red cabbage plain or vinegar-based, or is it a mayonnaise/cream-dressed coleslaw?
